title: FITS image writing refactor

content.raw:
What do you think about defining `FITSImageBuffer` as an alias for `FITSImageData` in `yt.utilities.fits_image`?  What about other API changes?  If they're substantial enough, should we leave behind the whole FITSImageBuffer class, mark it as deprecated, and remove it in yt 4.0?

I'm not sure how big the userbase for this feature is but I hate to break APIs for things that aren't explicitly marked as experimental.
content.html:
What do you think about defining FITSImageBuffer as an alias for FITSImageData in yt.utilities.fits_image? What about other API changes? If they're substantial enough, should we leave behind the whole FITSImageBuffer class, mark it as deprecated, and remove it in yt 4.0?

I'm not sure how big the userbase for this feature is but I hate to break APIs for things that aren't explicitly marked as experimental.

content.raw: Since you're grabbing `.v` do you think you could perform unit conversion first?
content.html: Since you're grabbing .v do you think you could perform unit conversion first?

Sorry--could you elaborate?

Also, I think these lines are here because I just moved it from above and added an underscore--but that doesn't mean I won't gladly take comments on it. :)

Sorry--could you elaborate?

content.raw: Sure -- `.v` drops all units, right?  So we want to make sure, before we do that, that they are in the *right* units.  So converting first, then dropping units.
content.html: Sure -- .v drops all units, right? So we want to make sure, before we do that, that they are in the right units. So converting first, then dropping units.

content.raw: I see no reason this can't go in -- it's a pretty robust PR with new tests.  Since we have a three-reviewer requirement for changes like this, can I solicit an eyeball from @brittonsmith or @xarthisius?
content.html: I see no reason this can't go in -- it's a pretty robust PR with new tests. Since we have a three-reviewer requirement for changes like this, can I solicit an eyeball from Britton Smith or Kacper Kowalik?

description:
A while back, I put in capabilities for writing 2D or 3D NumPy arrays from FRBs, CoveringGrids, or whatever to FITS images, with additional coordinate information. This PR represents a refactor of that functionality, with some new capabilities. 

1. I renamed the `FITSImageBuffer` class to `FITSImageData`, since it is a bit more accurate of a name. An alias to the old name has been added. 
2. Added class methods for creating `FITSImageData` instances from FITS files previously written to disk, and combining a number of `FITSImageData` instances into one. 
3. `create_sky_wcs` is now a method of `FITSImageData`, which allows one to quickly take a FITS image with linear coordinates, and convert it to one with a celestial coordinate system, given an angular scale and center coordinates. Other options for tweaking the coordinates are also available.
4. Remove a field from the `FITSImageData` instance with `pop`.  
5. I added testing support for `FITSImageData` as well. 
6. Other various helper methods have been added. 
7. Writing directly to FITS images from off axis slices and projections has been added. 

In addition, I did the following:

* The documentation has been updated to reflect the new changes, and explains essentially all of the new functionality. To get a sense of what this code is doing, I recommend looking at the FITSImageData.ipynb notebook, which you can find a completed version of here: https://gist.github.com/70d3dd03221bb7106d13
* I also updated whatever parts of the code that were using `FITSImageBuffer`, including volume rendering, FRB generation, `PPVCube`, and `sunyaev_zeldovich`. 
* I fixed a double return statement in off axis projections that probably wasn't hurting anyone, but shouldn't have been there. 

UPDATE: After some reflection on @ngoldbaum's comment, I reverted a couple of the API changes that weren't strictly necessary (decided I didn't even really want them), and created an alias to `FITSImageBuffer`.
